item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Some Cabinet Work
item.description: Over the weekend, I made progress reassembling the Beogram 4002, focusing on the cabinet trim and deck cover. To prevent damage, I had previously removed the rosewood trim. The trim is attached to a metal frame that slides in and out to lock and unlock the cabinet. This frame relies on five guide washers, which are commonly broken in Beogram 4002 units. This one was no different. These washers have a unique design, as detailed in a past Beolover blog post.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Alternate "Circuit Diagram 2" with 24V Scale Illumination Lamps
item.description: I recently acquired a well-preserved Beogram 4000 service manual containing a unique supplementary diagram. This diagram, Circuit Diagram 2, outlines the control system and features a notable difference in the position scale illumination. Instead of the typical two 12V bulbs wired in series, it depicts two 24V bulbs connected in parallel to the 24V power source. This discovery complicated a recent interaction with Sonavor, who is currently restoring his own Beogram 4000.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing the RAM Battery
item.description: The Beocord 9000 utilizes a 3V battery to power its 16-word memory chip, an MCM144102, which is described as a peripheral memory unit in the Motorola 6804 manual but lacks readily available detailed specifications. This chip is responsible for storing calibration data and potentially the system time, although further investigation is required. A visual representation of the circuit is included below. A positive aspect of the design is the inclusion of diode D27, which safeguards the battery against reverse polarity connection.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Lubrication of Platter Motor Bearings
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), the DC motor was lubricated. This particular motor uses brushes and has simple sleeve bearings. To access the bearings for lubrication, the pulley and outer housing were removed. The pulley is attached to the shaft with glue, allowing for easy removal. After taking out two small screws, the housing can be opened and the motor taken out. Next, the black rubber vibration insulation boot was removed, revealing the circuit board connected to the brushes.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Cosmetic Items, Final Adjustments, and a Test Drive with George Duke on MPS!
item.description: The Beogram 4000 restoration project, originating from Germany, is nearing completion. After adjusting the sub-chassis and arm height, I set the arm lowering limit, a crucial measure to protect the stylus from potential damage if the record detection fails. Next, I calibrated the tracking weight, opting to enhance stability by replacing the original locking washer setup with an M3 nut and washer to secure the counterweight position. Following that, I calibrated the arm weight using a digital scale and fine-tuned the feedback by adjusting the tracking sensor LED with a blue potentiometer.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): A New Arrival from California
item.description: I recently acquired a Beogram 4002 (Type 5503; AC platter motor) turntable for restoration. The unit arrived in remarkably good shape. The dust cover is practically flawless, and the aluminum panels and platter are in fantastic condition. However, there is a hole drilled into the top left corner of the aluminum plate surrounding the platter, meaning this part will need replacement. Thankfully, beneath the plates, the turntable appears to be in pristine, original condition.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Installation of New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description: Replacing the original DIN or RCA plugs is a crucial step when restoring a Beogram 4002. The old plugs often show corrosion due to the lack of gold plating. Upgrading to modern, all-metal plugs with gold-plated terminals is recommended. This upgrade minimizes electromagnetic interference and ensures optimal signal transfer to the amplifier by maintaining low contact resistance, especially important for the delicate MMC20 cartridge signals. The original RCA plugs on a Beogram 4002 (5513) being restored were in poor condition.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the RPM Indicator Light Bulbs with LEDs
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), the incandescent bulbs in the RPM indicator panels were replaced with LED-based alternatives. This change aimed to enhance the stability of the DC motor control system by reducing heat generation, a common issue with traditional bulbs. The new SMD LED circuits, designed for a seamless drop-in replacement, feature red and green LEDs calibrated to mimic the warm glow of incandescent lighting. This spectrum, especially the inclusion of red photons, ensures accurate illumination of the red plastic RPM indicators.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): First Impressions
item.description: A Beogram 4002, model 5514, recently arrived in its original packaging, complete with styrofoam, which is remarkable! The platter was separately packaged in a vinyl box for added protection. The turntable is in excellent cosmetic condition, requiring only cleaning. Even the keypad is in good shape, though using a 4002 Commander remote control could help prevent future wear. The veneer corners are flawless, and the internal components appear untouched. Initial testing showed the turntable powers on and the motor functions, but the arm doesn’t lower.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival From Massachusetts - First Look
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable arrived from a Massachusetts customer for a complete restoration. Thankfully, it was properly packaged and arrived without damage. The turntable’s dust cover shows typical signs of use, but it will be replaced with a new one. The aluminum surfaces are in good shape overall. However, there are some minor flaws. The keypad has a corner ding, suggesting it might have come loose during past transportation. Additionally, there are small scratches on the aluminum, possibly from the keypad moving around.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): New Gold Plated RCA Plugs
item.description: Over time, many Beogram devices have developed corroded DIN or RCA plugs. It’s a good idea to replace these old connectors with new, gold-plated ones. This specific Beogram 4002 (5513) came with RCA connectors. I typically use large, modern, high-quality metal plugs for replacements. However, this project had a unique requirement: the Beogram needed to connect to a Beolab 5000. The Beolab 5000 has a compact compartment for its connectors, which creates limitations on plug size.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4716/4715): Removing the Drive Mechanism
item.description: Note: This post documents an outdated method. There’s a simpler way to remove the drive that doesn’t involve lifting the Pre-Amplifier board or disconnecting the solenoid linkage. See my later post for the updated procedure. Following advice from ‘chartz’ and ‘sonavor’ on Beoworld.org (link to thread), I began replacing the belts in my Beocord 5000 (4716), which had become loose and stretched over time. The first step is removing the drive mechanism.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the Main PCB and Installation of a Biasing Trimmer for TR3
item.description: After getting the Beogram 4002 (5513) operational again, I focused on fully restoring the main PCB. This involved installing a trimmer to correctly calibrate TR3, the transistor responsible for amplifying the signal from the record detection sensor. The board’s condition upon arrival is shown below: The RPM relay and trimmers had already been replaced by the owner. I finished the restoration by replacing all electrolytic capacitors and adding a trimmer to enable bias adjustment at the base of TR3.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoring the Hood
item.description: Restoring a Beogram often includes restoring its hood, as many have accumulated scratches over time. This particular Beogram 4002 (5513) had deep scratches on its hood. The restoration started by sanding with 220-grit sandpaper, then progressively moved to finer grits (320-grit shown). This process, which took about 3 hours and involved around 10 polishing steps with Micro-Mesh up to 12000 level, returned the hood to a translucent and shiny condition.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Service Manual Adjustments & Preparing for Use
item.description: In the previous post, I finished cleaning and deoxidizing the keypad and RPM panel. The keypad is now responsive, but the cueing up and down button is overly sensitive and needs further attention. The RPM panel re-installation was put on hold because the plastic mounting fixtures were cracked, a common issue with Beogram 4002 turntables. I was fortunate that the cracks weren’t severe and the fixtures were still usable. To repair them, I used acrylic repair fluid while pressing the pieces together.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the Output Board, Installation of a Grounding Switch and Repair of the Keypad
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration is almost done. Today, I worked on Output PCB #8 and fixed a loose key on the keypad. The Output PCB #8 was initially in this condition: I prefer to replace the output relay as they tend to get stuck with age. Luckily, the relay is the same one used for platter RPM switching, so my custom replacement boards work here as well: These replacement parts are available to anyone interested; feel free to email me.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513) Remote Control: Final 3D Printed Part Added
item.description: I have completed the final 3D printed component for my Beogram 4002 (5513) remote control system. This piece fits into a 10mm opening on the remote control receiver board, allowing it to be secured using one of the main PCB’s screws. The image below shows the part with the screw in place: Once the remote control board is in place, the original screw can be used to fasten it. The cylindrical portion is designed to prevent the remote board from pressing against the component pins on the Beogram’s main PCB while ensuring a secure fit.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of PCBs
item.description: Following the restoration of the arm lowering and tracking mechanisms on a Beogram 4002 turntable, the subsequent task involves refurbishing the printed circuit boards (PCBs) and replacing the reservoir capacitor. The initial focus is on the main PCB. It was in its original state, showing signs of age and use. A detailed view highlights the RPM control section, which was particularly important for speed stability. All electrolytic capacitors on the board were replaced with new, high-quality Japanese components rated for 105 degrees Celsius.

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Initial Assessment
item.description: This Beogram 8002 turntable, sent from California, is the next restoration project. I prefer working on the same type of audio equipment consecutively because it minimizes workbench setup time. The owner followed our packing advice and packaged the turntable very well, using double boxes and protective foam. The turntable arrived without damage. Upon opening, I noticed the metal tonearm lid wouldn’t stay up. The part that connects to the hinge with damping grease was detached, a problem I haven’t encountered before.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Keypad and RPM Panel
item.description: Slow response times from the Beogram’s control panel buttons pointed to potential oxidation on the keypad contacts. This was confirmed upon opening the keypad assembly, revealing dull key contacts. The contact pads were unsoldered and removed for a closer look. While they seemed okay, the leaf contacts engaged by the actuators showed signs of oxidation. To address the oxidation, a fiberglass brush and Deoxit were used, restoring the contacts to a shiny and clean condition.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Gold-Plating of the Carriage Position Switch Terminals
item.description: My Beogram 4000 restoration continued with gold-plating the carriage position switch terminals to address a common issue. In my experience, about 90% of problems with this B&O model stem from oxidized switch terminals. These switches are critical because they inform the digital control system about the carriage’s position. Malfunctioning switches lead to a confused control system, so gold-plating is recommended for its resistance to oxidation, ensuring long-term reliability. While not the worst I’ve seen in these models, the black spots indicate some oxidation was present.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the DC Motor - Oil Infusion of Bearings, and Repair of a Broken Off Brush and a Disconnected Sensing Coil
item.description: I recently received a Beogram 4002 (5513) DC motor from the Netherlands. The motor was dead on arrival, so I opened it up and discovered a broken commutator spring that had been taped on with electrical tape. Unsurprisingly, the motor wouldn’t turn. I also found a broken lead on one of the sensing coils, which should have a resistance of 22 Ohms between the contact terminals. This break disabled the motor’s feedback mechanism.

item.title: Beocord 5000 Type 4923: New power supply capacitors and belts
item.description: In the last update on this Beocord 5000 (Type 4923), I was about to install new belts and replace the power supply’s electrolytic capacitors. This post covers the completion of those tasks. The original power supply capacitors are shown below. …and the replacement capacitors are here. Next up are the belts. First is the tape counter belt. Now for the clutch wheel and flywheel belts. Replacing these requires disassembling some brackets.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5521): Replacing the Tracking Sensor Light Bulb with a SMD LED
item.description: The Beogram 4002 I’m currently working on had a faulty tracking sensor light bulb. To fix it, I used my custom-designed SMD LED replacement part, which is a direct swap for the original bulb housing. This component was recently updated during a Beogram 4000 restoration to incorporate an integrated intensity trimmer. This trimmer simplifies the process of adjusting the tracking sensor feedback significantly. It enables fine-tuning after the light sensors are mechanically positioned below the light source.

item.title: Beogram 4002: From Oil Cleanup to First Operational Test
item.description: The Beogram 4002 restoration hit a snag. Although the main board was restored, the presence of rust and corrosion discovered earlier took priority. Addressing rust requires applying neutralizer and paint, which involves drying time between coats, thus delaying the planned reservoir capacitor and output board work. Images highlighting the most severe rust spots are included. Despite the significant rust, the turntable’s overall condition is good. To combat the rust, three coats of rust neutralizer were applied.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of Worn Keypad
item.description: I’m currently working on restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable and have reached the stage of addressing cosmetic details. A common issue with this model, as with approximately 90% of them, is a worn keypad. The original coating deteriorates over time due to exposure to skin oils and acids. This results in unsightly smudges, especially on units that have seen regular use. I recently acquired some refurbished keypads from a contact in Denmark to have on hand for my restoration projects.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Main and Power Supply PCBs
item.description: Following the replacement of the reservoir and motor capacitors on the Beogram 4000, the next stage was to focus on the main and power supply PCBs. It’s recommended to replace the RPM relay and trimmers alongside the electrolytic capacitors due to their susceptibility to corrosion. The main PCB in its original state can be seen here: A closer look at the outdated Siemens relay and RPM trimmers: And the outcome after component replacement:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Restoring the DC Platter Motor
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5523) restoration continued with a focus on the motor. The motor was noticeably loud, a common issue in DC 4002 models often caused by dried lubricant in the sleeve bearings. Addressing this requires disassembling the motor, cleaning it, and applying fresh lubricant. The first image highlights the upper sleeve bearing after the rotor was removed. The next image provides a view of the lower bearing, feedback coils, and brushes.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Installation of a New Output Relay and a GND Switch
item.description: During the testing of a restored Beogram 4002 (5513), I discovered an intermittent issue with the output relay. Occasionally, it wouldn’t activate when the stylus made contact, blocking the audio signal from the amplifier. This was a fortunate problem since the relay is the same one used for RPM switching in the 4002 and 4000 models. I had previously designed a breakout board to replace the RPM relay in a Beogram 4000 with a modern, encapsulated SMD signal relay, and I was able to utilize this board in the 4002 repair.

item.title: A Pair of Beomaster 1900 Receivers for Restoration: Recapping the Tone Control & FM Tuning Board (Unit #1)
item.description: The final major task in the Beomaster 1900 restoration, detailed in the previous post, has been completed. This post covers the last board requiring capacitor replacements: the Tone Control & FM Tuning Board. Replacing the ten capacitors on this board is straightforward due to their accessibility. The true challenge lies in cleaning and fixing the three slider controls: Bass, Treble, and Balance. Before images of the Tone Control & FM Tuning Board are shown below.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Slow Rewinding, Inconsistent Pause Function and Auto Stop
item.description: After reinstalling the drive unit into the Beocord 5000 (4715), I began testing. Initial impressions were positive, with fast forward, rewind, play, and stop functions all working. However, the Auto Stop function would cease working after a few minutes. The tape would reach the end, but the drive mechanism would continue running, potentially harming the motor. The only solution was to turn off the deck for an hour to reset the function.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Final Tasks, Adjustments & Playing Records
item.description: The final steps of a Beogram 4002 Type 5513 restoration project involved addressing corrosion damage and replacing the 5-pin DIN phono plug. Using a helpful audio path diagram, continuity checks were performed from the cartridge connector to ensure proper signal flow. The replacement phono plug, a REAN model with gold contact pins, was installed, though the tight fit of the rubber boot on the cable posed a minor challenge. As an improvement, a grounding switch was added to the output board, eliminating the need for an external grounding wire.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Infusing Oilite Brass Bearings of DC Motor with Oil Under Vacuum
item.description: Restoring the DC motors found in Beogram 4002/4 turntables (models 551x and 552x) presents a significant challenge. Many of these motors exhibit loud operation and inconsistent rotational speed due to their age. While lubricating the motor’s brass sleeve bearings with grease might seem like a solution, this often only yields temporary improvement. The root of the issue lies in the use of ‘oilite’ bearings, which are designed to operate without external lubrication.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Electrolytic Capacitors
item.description: During my Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration project, I focused on replacing components. Using a custom 3D-printed adapter, I substituted the large 4700/1000uF capacitor with modern, compact 105C-rated alternatives. The adapter ensured compatibility with the original mounting hardware. Following this, I replaced all the tantalum and electrolytic capacitors on the main circuit board, refreshing its components for improved reliability and performance. The only remaining capacitor, located on the output relay board, will be replaced when I disassemble the keypad to install a professionally refurbished replacement sourced from a Danish Beo expert.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): New Gold Plated DIN Plug
item.description: During the ongoing refurbishment of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, a corroded DIN5 plug was replaced after a new output relay had been installed. The original plug showed significant signs of wear. A high-quality Rean DIN5 plug with gold-plated terminals was chosen as a replacement. Photos document the preparation of the cable and the installation process. The author notes the limited space inside the DIN5 plug, making it difficult to separate the signal and ground connections.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor: Spark Snubber Replacement
item.description: I recently had a Beogram 4002 DC platter motor on my workbench that I had previously worked on in November 2016 due to a broken brush and a severed pickup coil lead. The motor recently began experiencing RPM fluctuations again. This pointed to a problem with the spark snubbers. To access the rotor, I opened the motor: The spark snubbers, marked with red dots, are located around the commutator. The replacements are on the black pad.

item.title: Beogram 4002: DC Motor Restoration and RPM Stability Test
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC motor from France was received for restoration. As is typical, the motor’s Oilite brass bearings needed fresh oil. This requires disassembling the motor and extracting the bearings for a vacuum oiling process. The bearings were submerged in motor oil under vacuum, forcing air out of the porous material and drawing oil in. This process generally takes about 24 hours. This shows the bearings after the oil infusion.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival from Germany En Route to California
item.description: I recently acquired a Beogram 4000 turntable from Germany, intended for a customer in California. My task is to refurbish the unit and deliver it to its new owner. The turntable was poorly packaged for shipment, resulting in the keypad plates becoming detached during transit. This led to minor damage to the plates themselves and some cosmetic imperfections on other internal surfaces. The aluminum surfaces are in surprisingly good shape considering the loose keypad plates.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A new Arrival from Nebraska
item.description: A Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable from Nebraska arrived for a complete restoration. It was securely shipped in a Beolover container. This is my first look at the unit. Upon unboxing and bench inspection: The turntable is in relatively good cosmetic condition. The dust cover is in good shape, though it would benefit from polishing. The aluminum surfaces show only minor imperfections: The base has one slightly worn corner on the right side:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Complete Restoration and Test Drive with Cal Tjader and Claus Ogerman
item.description: I recently began restoring a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable for an Australian customer who purchased it on eBay. The turntable arrived in poor condition. My initial evaluation is documented here. This post details the unit’s restoration, excluding the dust cover, which will be covered separately. I began with the DC platter motor, as is customary, since the bearing lubrication process requires a few days. Here’s the motor after removal:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Final Adjustments, Repair of a Damaged Pinth Corner and Test Drive with Bobby Hutcherson
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5523) restoration is nearing completion. Following the installation of new gold-plated RCA plugs, I made adjustments to the sub-chassis, platter height, and meticulously cleaned the aluminum surfaces. To prevent the needle from contacting the platter ribs if the record detection mechanism fails, I adjusted the arm’s lowering limit. Subsequently, I calibrated the tracking weight scale and enhanced the counterweight adjustment mechanism. The original flimsy circlip was replaced with a more durable M3 nut and washer setup, enhancing its resistance to transport-related stress.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Restoration of DC Motor and a Dead TR2 Transistor
item.description: After refreshing the PCBs and the RPM trimmer scale backlighting on a Beogram 4002 (5523) turntable, I turned my attention to its DC motor. Most DC motors in these models need their Oilite brass bearings replenished with oil, as the oil tends to seep out over time, leading to RPM instability. To do this, the motor needs to be disassembled. The bearings sit on a black pad within the motor. I noticed the motor had been previously repaired, evident in the bent brushes, which would have hindered its performance.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Test Drive
item.description: It’s a great day! My second Beocord 5000 (specifically models 4715/4716) is functional again and playing in sync with the rest of my setup: the Beomaster 6000 4-Channel and the Beogram 4002. To mark this occasion, I chose Sonny Rollins’ “Alfie” for the first recording. The movie “Alfie,” starring Michael Caine, is a personal favorite, and its soundtrack is incredible. Here are some snapshots from the listening session:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Final Touches - AC Motor Calibration, Adjusting Platter and Sub-Chassis and Tracking Force
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5501) restoration is nearly complete. After deep cleaning the aluminum panels and platter, I adjusted the sub-chassis and platter height, tonearm lowering limit, and tracking weight. There are videos on my YouTube channel demonstrating platter bearing and sub-chassis adjustments, similar for the 4000 and 4002 models. Another video covers the crucial adjustment of lowering limits, essential because the 4002’s system can’t always prevent damage from photosensor failure. Proper adjustment acts as a safeguard, potentially saving an expensive cartridge.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Sensor Arm Light Bulb
item.description: During the restoration of my Beogram 4002 (5513), I inspected the sensor arm light bulb and was surprised to find it in perfect condition. Unlike other bulbs I’ve encountered, which typically display a dark film on the glass due to filament evaporation, this one was spotless: This suggests that this particular Beogram was either lightly used or had its bulb replaced previously. As a result, I will not change it. However, the bulb’s placement within its compartment is worth noting.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Full Functional Restoration and Installation of Beolover Commander Remote
item.description: This document details the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable. Initial assessment of the unit can be found on a separate blog post. The restoration began with the platter motor, as its bearings require a lengthy oil treatment. The motor was extracted, disassembled, and its bearings were submerged in oil under a vacuum to allow for optimal oil diffusion. Concurrently, the carriage assembly was cleaned. All “motion critical” parts, including the arm and its associated mechanisms, were removed, ultrasonically cleaned, and reassembled.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Replacing the Original DIN5 Plug with a Modern All-Metal Gold Plated Unit
item.description: To fully restore a 4002, replacing the often corroded DIN5 connector is essential. The delicate low-voltage signals need optimal contact. Gold is an ideal material due to its resistance to oxidation, ensuring a strong and long-lasting connection. The pictures illustrate this process, showing the old connector’s condition, preparing the cable for the new connector, the soldering process, and finally, the pristine new gold-plated connector installed. This upgrade is a significant step towards bringing the Beogram back to its former glory.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): RPM Trimmer Illumination Very Low
item.description: After reviving the circuit boards of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, I focused on improving the dim backlighting of the 33 and 45 RPM adjustment scales. I removed the panel containing these adjustments for easier access. Taking off the light covers revealed the bulbs. A closer look showed that the bulbs were not the correct type, leading to the weak illumination. I replaced these bulbs with my custom-designed SMD LED replacements.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Non-Working End Groove Detection - Repair of a Detached Carriage Position Sensor
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration is nearly complete. One peculiar problem was a detached carriage position sensor, which is housed within a black light shield. This shield was hanging at an angle, but it needs to be positioned vertically. The sensor works by using black sections on a plexiglass strip attached to the carriage to interrupt light from an IR diode. If the sensor is misaligned, stray light can disrupt the carriage’s movement.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Stopover From Arizona on the Way to Portugal - A First Look
item.description: Our company provides a service where we assist customers in buying vintage audio equipment from online marketplaces and other sellers. We arrange shipping to our facility, restore the unit, and then deliver it to the customer. It’s almost like taking a trip back in time to buy a brand new unit! This post documents the unboxing of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable purchased on eBay from an Arizona seller for a customer in Portugal.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival and a First Look
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable from Norway recently arrived for restoration. The packaging was excellent, using the original styrofoam inserts, and the only issue was two loose control pads, which were prevented from causing damage due to tape and foam inside. This highlights the importance of securing these pads with non-residue tape during shipping. Fortunately, this is an easy repair. Cosmetically, the Beogram is in excellent condition. The aluminum panels will gleam like new with a thorough cleaning.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Oil Infusion of DC Platter Motor Bearings and RPM Test
item.description: To fully rebuild the platter drive system of a Beogram 4002 DC motor, you must relubricate the motor bearings. Many DC motor Beograms have fluctuating RPMs because the oil in their porous brass bearings (called “Oilite”) depletes over time. These bearings can be ‘refilled’ by using a vacuum to remove air and allow oil to replenish the pores. The challenge lies in extracting the bearings without causing damage. I documented this process in a recent video.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the PCBs
item.description: Following the repair of the Beogram 4002 (5513)’s arm lowering and tracking mechanisms, the next stage of restoration involved the electronics and platter drive. As usual, the process commenced with the replacement of all electrolytic capacitors on the printed circuit boards (PCBs) with new, high-quality Japanese capacitors rated for 105 degrees Celsius. To ensure the DC motor operates smoothly and without speed variations, the RPM relay was upgraded to a modern, enclosed unit, and 25-turn precision trimmers were installed for precise RPM adjustment.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Beogram 4002 Bonanza!
item.description: We seem to be inundated with Beogram 400x turntable restorations. Beolover is occupied with multiple projects, and I have two Beogram 4002 Type 5513 projects that I began examining back in February of 2020. In those previous posts, I had sent four Beogram 400x platter motors to Beolover for his restoration expertise. He has since completed those motors, and they are now back in my possession, ready to be used.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Final Adjustments, a New Solenoid, and Test Drive with Christoph Spendel & Wolfgang Schlüter Group on MPS
item.description: The final steps of restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) involved replacing the sensor arm light bulb with an LED assembly and performing standard adjustments. These included calibrating the tracking feedback, platter height, level, sub-chassis height, and arm lowering limit, which prevents stylus damage. To ensure accurate tracking weight calibration, the C-clip securing the counterweight adjustment screw was replaced with an M3 nut and washer for permanent fixation. This guarantees that the calibration remains consistent during shipping.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Complete Restoration Including a Refurbished Keypad and Commander Remote Control Module
item.description: This unit is currently for sale. Please, see here. This post details the complete restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) from Arizona, which I first inspected as shown here. The unit’s condition upon arrival is pictured below: My first step, as always, was to initiate oil infusion for the platter motor bearings. Here’s the motor after removal: I took it apart to extract the bearings (two small rings on the black pad):

item.title: Beocord 5000 Type 4923: Initial assessment of another Beosystem 5000 companion component.
item.description: This Beocord 5000 is the second cassette deck from Bang & Olufsen to bear this name. The original Beocord 5000, a Type 47xx model, was manufactured in the late 1970s. While distinct, both are high-quality cassette decks. [Image] [Image] The Beocord 5000 Type 4923 aligns with the Beomaster 5000 Type 2323 and the CD50 Beosystem 5000 components in terms of size and design. Control and display access are provided both on the front panel and through a master remote control.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Final Adjustments and a Test Drive with Freddie Hubbard's "The Love Connection"
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration project is finished after some final tuning. I made adjustments to the platter height and sub-chassis alignment, documenting the process for my YouTube channel. While my videos feature a Beogram 4000, the method for adjusting the platter bearing and sub-chassis are quite similar for the 4002 model. The arm lowering limit was the next step, a crucial adjustment to safeguard the cantilever if the record detection malfunctions.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Tangential Arm Assembly Oil Cleanup and Restoration
item.description: This Beogram 4002 restoration project continued with a thorough cleaning of the cabinet’s interior, focusing on removing oil residue. The tangential arm assembly was detached to access and clean the oil contamination found throughout the unit. The oil had spread extensively, affecting various components from the arm’s mechanics to the switch contacts. The tangential arm position sensor assembly was entirely disassembled for cleaning. With the old oil removed, the arm assembly restoration and adjustments could begin.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Second Unit From Houston
item.description: A few weeks back, I completed the first of two Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable restorations for a client in Houston. I’m now starting work on the second one. Both turntable platters had their motors removed before being sent to Beolover for refurbishment. He has since finished these and documented the process on his blog. I believe that refurbishing the platter motor is an essential step in any Beogram 400x restoration project.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Completing the Restoration and a Test Spin with Weather Report!
item.description: This Beogram 4000 restoration project is complete, and it’s time to review the work. Two previous posts covered specific repairs: addressing a missing transistor insulator and a faulty motor driver transistor, and creating a 3D printed replacement for the fragile MMC cartridge mounts. This post summarizes the remaining restoration work. Typically, the process begins with a complete overhaul of the turntable’s carriage. This involves disassembling and cleaning all moving parts, such as the arm lowering mechanism.

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Cabinet Work Completion to First Record Play
item.description: I finally set up the Beogram 8002 turntable in a listening room to test its functionality. While reassembly took a bit longer than expected due to a slight detour to repair chipped rosewood trim on the front panel. Although fixing the trim wasn’t part of the initial restoration plan, I decided against leaving the front panel chipped. Repairs involving glue, like this one, often take longer than expected due to the curing time.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Adjustment of Sub-Chassis, Platter Height, Tonearm Lowering Limits and Tracking Weight
item.description: After successfully positioning the top aluminum plates, I could adjust the sub-chassis and platter. This step is crucial as it sets the foundation for adjusting the arm lowering limits and, ultimately, the tracking force. This Beogram will be ready for an initial test run once this is completed. I’ve previously provided detailed explanations of the chassis and platter adjustment process on my blog and YouTube channel. Two videos demonstrate the platter bearing adjustment and the subchassis adjustment (using a Beogram 4000 as an example, although the procedure is almost identical for the 4002).

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing a Broken MMC Cartridge Mount with a 3D Printed Replacement Assembly
item.description: The first issue to tackle on this Beogram 4000 restoration was a damaged cartridge mount, a common problem on these turntables. The existing mount had a broken plastic piece. This particular unit came with both a damaged 4002 arm and its original, detached 4000 arm. The goal was to remove the 4002 arm and install the original arm after fitting it with a functional MMC mount. This project provided a perfect opportunity to use a recently designed 3D-printed replacement MMC mount.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Final Adjustments, Some Odds and Ends and a Test Drive with Cal Tjader
item.description: After switching the original black plinth with a teak one from a Beogram 4002, it was time for the final adjustments and a test run of the Beogram 4000 turntable. I started by setting the platter height, tilt, and alignment with the surrounding aluminum panels. Next, I adjusted the arm’s lowest point to make sure the needle wouldn’t touch the black ribs on the platter if the platter detection system malfunctioned.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Exciting DC Motor Failure Mode Due to a Shorted Spark Snubber
item.description: Another Beogram 4002 (5513) DC motor in need of repair recently came to my workbench. During my standard pre-restoration test using a Beogram 4002, this motor was unusually sluggish, only operating with assistance. This contrasted with the typical DC motors I encounter, which generally run powerfully but exhibit RPM fluctuations and often produce high-pitched sounds due to dried-out bearings. This particular motor was noticeably underpowered. I disassembled the motor and performed my usual bearing oil infusion to ensure the mechanical components were within specifications before addressing the sluggishness.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Keypad Restoration and LEDs for the RPM Indicators
item.description: The Beogram 4002 (5513) I’m currently working on had a significantly deteriorated keypad. The material used for these keypads tends to wear down over time due to the oils from fingerprints, making them a known weak point in this model. My friend in Denmark, who sadly passed away recently, was an expert at restoring these keypads. In his memory, I’ve been trying to learn his techniques. A couple of months ago, I started practicing, and I managed to successfully restore one keypad.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513 - DC Motor, Main PCB and RPM Panel Restoration
item.description: A Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable from Arizona was received for restoration, exhibiting the common issue of RPM fluctuations. To address this, the motor was prioritized, as revitalizing dry bearings with oil is a time-consuming process. The motor was disassembled to access the bearings. These were then submerged in motor oil within a vacuum environment. This process, characterized by vigorous bubbling, facilitates the oil’s penetration into the bearings’ porous material by drawing out trapped air.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the RPM Scales Light Bulbs with LEDs and a Further Improvement of the RPM Stability
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513), SMD LEDs were used to replace the incandescent bulbs that illuminate the RPM trimmer scales on the control panel. This modification involved using replacement boards that could be directly soldered onto the existing light bulb solder points. Images of the replacement boards and the installed LEDs are provided. These LED assemblies are available to other interested individuals. A video demonstrating the installation process is also available.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival From Germany - A First Peek
item.description: A Beogram 4000 turntable arrived from Germany for restoration, packaged securely with double boxes and separate protection for the platter. The inner box housed the Beogram within a styrofoam liner, while the two accompanying cartridges, an MMC20 E and an MMC20 EN, were packaged together. Unfortunately, the cartridges shifted during transit, causing the cantilever of the EN to press against the E cartridge’s plastic shroud. Thankfully, upon careful inspection, it appears that both cantilevers remain undamaged.

item.title: Beogram 4002: Replacing the RPM Indicator Bulbs with SMD LEDs
item.description: I’m currently restoring a Beogram 4002 (5513) and have been systematically replacing its lightbulbs. Today’s focus was the RPM indicator, which allowed me to refine my LED replacement method. Previously, I detailed a process using red and green LEDs from an RGB through-hole 5mm LED to replace the incandescent bulbs. While somewhat successful, the backlighting of the RPM trimmer scales lacked uniformity. Standard through-hole LEDs emit light directionally, requiring me to sand their bulbs for a matte finish and paint the tops black to minimize uneven brightness.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Complete Functional Restoration and Installation of Commander Remote Control System
item.description: This article details the restoration process of a Beogram 4002 (5523) turntable, aiming for like-new performance. The restoration began with addressing the DC platter motor, a common area of concern in these models. The motor was carefully removed and disassembled, and its bearings, often found dry, underwent a revitalization process. This involved immersing them in motor oil and applying a vacuum to draw out air and facilitate oil penetration. Simultaneously, the carriage and arm-lowering mechanisms were cleaned and re-lubricated.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): Final Adjustments and a Test Drive with Chico Hamilton on Auto-Repeat!
item.description: It was time for the final adjustments on the Beogram 4002 (5514) restoration project. Adjusting the platter and sub-chassis, arm lowering limits, and tracking force is always a satisfying part of the process. It means the turntable is ready for its initial post-restoration playback. Observing the intricate mechanics in motion, bringing out the best in vintage vinyl, is always captivating. This Beogram presented a unique sub-chassis and platter adjustment challenge. The platter was positioned too close to the front right edge of the aluminum plate cutout.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Restoration of RPM Trimmer Panel
item.description: Following the PCB rebuild of a Beogram 4002 (5501) turntable, the author focused on restoring the RPM trimmer panel, which had been previously replaced due to a burned-out illumination bulb. The first step involved re-soldering the connections where the original panel had been cut off and adding heat-shrink tubing for protection. LED replacement boards, specifically designed for the 550x series, were installed to provide similar resistance and current draw as the original bulbs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5514): Installation of a New DIN5 Plug With Gold Coated Terminals
item.description: My Beogram 4002 (5514) restoration is coming along nicely. I believe a key part of revitalizing these turntables is installing a new, all-metal DIN 5 plug with gold-plated contacts. The old plugs often suffer from corrosion, which hinders the delicate signal transfer from the MMC cartridge. For example, here’s a picture of the old plug with tarnished terminals: This image showcases the soldering work within the updated plug: And finally, the finished product:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Floating Suspension, Reservoir Capacitor & Platter Motor
item.description: This project is nearing completion. This post details the remounting of the floating chassis within the cabinet, replacing the reservoir capacitor, and installing the refurbished platter motor. Here are the parts needed for mounting the floating suspension system back into the cabinet. The threaded pin’s longer section is positioned at the bottom. When attaching the wing-nut, ensure it sits at the very beginning of the thread. I personally position it to allow enough thread for securing the nut while keeping the nut’s outer edge aligned with the topmost thread.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (Type 5513): Full Functional Restoration
item.description: This blog post details the functional restoration of a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) turntable from a client in Florida. A previous post documented the initial assessment of the unit. Upon beginning the restoration, the turntable was in relatively original condition. However, the platter motor showed signs of prior work, evidenced by an incorrectly installed pulley. To address this, the motor was removed and disassembled to extract and lubricate the bearings. This involved immersing them in motor oil under vacuum until air bubbles ceased to appear, indicating the bearings were properly saturated.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacing all Electrolytic Capacitors and the RPM Relay
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4000 turntable, a humming sound and vibration from the solenoid were traced back to a faulty 30V power supply. The reservoir capacitance was depleted, causing instability in the solenoid’s power supply and preventing the arm lowering mechanism from functioning correctly. To address this, the reservoir and motor capacitors were rebuilt. A custom-designed 3D printed part was used to house the new capacitors, ensuring a secure fit within the original capacitor bay.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Fit and Finish Rework
item.description: Restoring Beogram 4002 turntables is a fulfilling endeavor, though it often necessitates revisiting steps multiple times. Despite getting this particular Beogram functioning properly, I was dissatisfied with the fit of some components. The tonearm cover wasn’t sitting flush, as evidenced by its crooked appearance in the photo, with the center divider visibly off-center between the fixed arm and tonearm. A head-on perspective further highlights this issue, along with the misaligned deck trim, showing an undesirably wide gap between the panels.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5521): Replacing the Deteriorated Transport Lock Bushings
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002, deteriorated transport lock bushings, evidenced by small orange plastic pieces within the unit, were discovered. To address this, 3D-printed replacement bushings were designed for convenient installation without major disassembly. These bushings are comprised of two halves, insertable from above and below the sub-chassis. The replacement bushings are available for purchase, with each bushing requiring two of the 3D-printed parts. A video detailing the installation process is accessible online.

item.title: Beocord 5000 Type 4923: A couple of service manual retests and wrapping up the project
item.description: The Beocord 5000 (Type 4923) is performing very well in recording and playback testing. This stage of restoration always highlights the quality of the component. While it lacks auto-reverse and a monitoring tape head, the Beocord 5000 is a high-quality cassette deck with features some users prefer. The previous post detailed the electrical adjustments outlined in the service manual. These procedures, while not overly complex, necessitate specialized calibration tapes and testing equipment.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Floating Chassis
item.description: This short post will illustrate an intriguing difference in the suspension systems of two Beogram 4002 Type 5513 turntables. The first Beogram 4002 Type 5513, serial number 1312615, used a stack of concave washers to secure the floating suspension to the top plate. These washers were also present on the bottom lock. The second Beogram 4002 Type 5513, serial number 1311076, features a slightly different suspension mechanism. This earlier production model employs a single, concave metal piece between the suspension lock and the top plate.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5521): Adjusting Platter and Chassis
item.description: The visual appeal of a Beogram 400x relies heavily on the platter’s alignment with its surrounding aluminum panels. A correctly aligned platter sits flush with these panels, allowing the black ‘ribs’ to stand out against a flat aluminum surface. Achieving this alignment is intricate, requiring several parameters to be perfectly adjusted. I’ve observed that a sensor arm that isn’t entirely parallel to the floating chassis often complicates this process. Both the service manual and my videos detail an adjustment procedure assuming the sensor arm’s parallelism.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Platter Motor: Replacement of Spark Snubbers
item.description: A Beogram 4002 (5513) DC platter motor, previously restored in 2016, displayed RPM fluctuations and required attention. Although the motor’s bearings had been treated with oil at that time, the spark snubbers were not replaced. The motor had functioned correctly following the initial restoration. Initial testing involved installing the motor in a 4002 turntable and monitoring its RPM stability over 24 hours. The results are represented by the blue line in the provided graph.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5524): Full Functional Restoration and Installation of Beolover Commander Remote
item.description: This article details the restoration process of a Beogram 4002 turntable from Texas, following an initial assessment. The author mentions a slight delay due to relocating to Albuquerque. The turntable was mostly original, suggesting a straightforward restoration. The process began with the DC platter motor, which is typical for these units. After nearly 50 years of use, the motor’s Oilite bearings needed re-lubrication. This involved disassembling the motor, immersing the bearings in oil, and creating a vacuum to help the oil penetrate.

item.title: Beogram 4000/4002/4004 Relays: Professionally Manufactured PCBs!
item.description: I recently updated the design of the Beogram 4000/4002/4004 relay adapter boards to allow for professional manufacturing. I’ve begun taking and fulfilling orders with these new boards, and I’m thrilled with how they turned out. Here’s a look at the boards: These boards are compatible with both the older Siemens relays and the newer National relays commonly found as RPM and signal path grounding relays in the 400x series. They are designed as direct replacements for the original relays.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): Hood Restoration
item.description: I am currently restoring a Beogram 4002 (5503) and focused on refurbishing its dust cover. As you can see in the first image, the cover had multiple scratches and abrasions common for its age. My first step was to sand the cover using 220-grit sandpaper to smooth out the imperfections. Following this, I used a Micro-Mesh polishing cloth to restore the cover’s clarity. The final result is a clear and revitalized dust cover.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Inside Work
item.description: My work on restoring a Beogram 4002 turntable from Houston continues, focusing on the internal components this time. This update covers the refurbishment of the tangential arm assembly and the replacement of the Beogram’s reservoir capacitor. Here’s a current picture of the Beogram 4002 with its chassis and tangential arm assembly removed. The tangential arm assembly components on this Beogram 4002 are in great condition. My work mainly involved cleaning and lubricating the Beogram chassis parts.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Restoration of DC Platter Motor, PCBs and RPM Panel
item.description: I recently obtained the DC platter motor, circuit boards, and RPM panel from a Beogram 4002 (5513) located in California. I began with the motor, as is customary, because it requires a few days for the oil to fully permeate the bearings. To begin, I took the motor apart to access the bearings. Then, I submerged the bearings in motor oil and created a vacuum. This process helps to remove air from the bearing material, allowing the oil to penetrate more effectively.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoration of the Keypad
item.description: Following the restoration of the Beogram 4000’s arm carriage, attention shifted to the keypad—the turntable’s control center housing the early digital control system. A single screw secures the keypad, allowing access to its internal components. Uniquely, this keypad lacked visible wiring underneath, unlike other 4000 models with wiring behind the latch. Instead, the wiring harness was cleverly routed into the pad from the front, simplifying reassembly. The restoration process began by addressing the fragile light bulbs illuminating the arm position scale and RPM trimmers.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of RPM Trimmer Panel Bulbs with LED Assemblies
item.description: Following the electronic restoration of a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, the next step was to upgrade the light bulbs in the RPM adjustment panel with LED assemblies. This change was made because LEDs offer greater longevity and produce less heat compared to incandescent bulbs. Reduced heat generation is particularly beneficial as it improves the stability of the DC motor responsible for driving the platter. The original RPM control panel, in a disassembled state, is depicted below.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A Very Corroded New Arrival from Sweden
item.description: My initial assessment of the Beogram 4000 from Sweden is a mixed bag. Positively, the aluminum surfaces, platter, arm cover lettering, and panels are in good shape, though a thorough cleaning is needed to determine their true condition. The internal components appear original, and the red position indicator is intact. However, there are significant drawbacks. The black enclosure parts have an unprecedented amount of corrosion, exceeding typical wear and tear. This corrosion is present even on the underside and has also affected the chassis’s leaf springs.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): New Arrival from Arizona - A First Look
item.description: I recently received a Beogram 4002 (Type 5513) from Arizona. It needed complete functional restoration. The unit arrived without its cover, shipped in a Beolover container, which is a great way to ensure safe transportation. Here’s the unit as it looked when unpacked: While a little dirty, it’s in decent condition except for the worn-out keypad: Hopefully, these keypads can be professionally refurbished. On a positive note, the base is in good shape, with almost pristine corners:

item.title: Beogram 4002: DC Motor Restoration and Dependence of RPM Performance on the Value of C10
item.description: I recently obtained two DC motors from Beogram 4002 turntables that are being refurbished. One of the motors is pictured here. The first step in restoring these motors is addressing the brass sleeve bearings, which are often dry after more than 35 years of use. I do this through an oil infusion process, which requires complete disassembly, as shown. The bearings, visible on the black pad in the front, are submerged in oil and placed under vacuum.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Intermittent "17" Position Switch Causing Immediate Touchdown After Launch
item.description: I thought I was finished with this Beogram 4000 turntable after refurbishing its dust cover. However, a new problem emerged. After playing a few records, the tonearm would drop next to the platter as soon as I pressed “ON.” Luckily, the stylus wasn’t damaged (thanks to proper arm height adjustment), but I clearly needed to examine the carriage mechanism’s “17” position switch. This particular switch is the most troublesome of the position switches because it’s the only “break switch.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Installing Rebuilt Rubber Pinch Rollers
item.description: Thorough testing of the Beocord 5000 (4715/4716) tape deck revealed an occasional issue where the leading capstan would cease to move the tape forward. This occurred under specific conditions, particularly when humidity hovered around 60% and room temperature dipped below 65°F. As a result, the supply capstan would continue to push the tape forward, causing it to slip out of place between the erase head and the supply pinch roller. Fortunately, the Beocord’s auto-stop function activated quickly enough to prevent damage to the tape.

item.title: Beogram 4002: A New Day, a New Hood!
item.description: I recently got a new dust cover for a Beogram turntable from Beoparts-shop in Denmark. These covers are made using the same injection molding process as the originals, so they have a seamless look, unlike older reproduction covers that were made by fusing together laser-cut pieces. The result is a cover that’s indistinguishable from the original. This photo shows the new cover: The hinge for the cover was missing the small plastic pieces that prevent the spring mechanism from rubbing against the hinge’s metal parts.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Replacement of Degraded Transport Lock Bushings with 3D Printed Replacement Parts
item.description: Following the repair of the Beogram 4002 (5523) arm lowering mechanism, I removed the circuit boards for refurbishment. This presented an ideal opportunity to swap the deteriorated transport lock bushings with 3D-printed replacements. The old bushings tend to break down, scattering fragments within the Beogram’s casing, often lodging beneath the floating chassis. These fragments can obstruct the chassis’s movement, hindering its ability to isolate the turntable and tonearm from the enclosure.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Replacement of Sensor Arm Light Bulb with an LED
item.description: The last incandescent bulb in this Beogram 4000 restoration project was replaced with an LED. Located within the sensor arm, this particular LED presented the biggest challenge due to the tight space. The solution involved creating a custom flexible PCB equipped with a current limiting resistor and a bypass to mimic the higher energy draw of a traditional light bulb. This was necessary because the control system relies on the current to confirm the bulb’s functionality.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Houston Beogram #3 Ready for Action Again
item.description: My favorite stage of the Beogram 4002 restoration is here. The only remaining tasks are some enjoyable record-playing tests in my office. I find listening to records through a favorite system while working far more pleasurable than watching television…and it’s a necessary job that someone has to do. I’m truly happy with how this Beogram turned out. Knowing this turntable has been meticulously serviced is a great feeling. It’s spotless inside, and Beolover did an exceptional job revitalizing the platter motor.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Installation of a New Plexiglass Hood and Aluminum Trim
item.description: The restoration of my Beogram 4000 is nearly complete. The final cosmetic touch was adding a new, reproduction dust cover from Classic Audio in Denmark. They also supplied a matching aluminum trim piece for the back edge. Installing the dust cover was simple. Here’s a look at the process: This image showcases the original hinge being installed with new stainless steel screws: The pre-drilled holes in the new cover aligned perfectly, and the screws went in just like the original.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5521): Replacing the RPM Scale Illumination Bulbs with SMD LEDs
item.description: Following the replacement of the tracking sensor’s light source, the next stage in restoring my Beogram 4002 (5521) involved addressing the incandescent bulbs within the RPM trimmer panel. The 33 RPM bulb had burned out, prompting the decision to replace both bulbs with custom-designed SMD LED assemblies. Recognizing the importance of a red light component for illuminating the red RPM indicators, red-green LEDs were chosen. While amber LEDs offer an incandescent-like aesthetic, their narrow wavelength distribution hinders their ability to effectively illuminate red surfaces.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513) Remote Control: Now With a 3D Printed Installation Tray
item.description: This post continues the discussion about my Beogram 4002 (5513) remote control upgrade, specifically the receiver board insulation. My previous solution, using plastic foil, wasn’t ideal aesthetically. To address this, I designed a plastic tray that safeguards the receiver board from the main circuit board’s solder points. The tray is designed to click into place without additional screws. Here are some photos: Tray and board before assembly: The tray features three rectangular cutouts to provide clearance for the solder points.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoring the Carriage Position and Solenoid Driven Switches
item.description: Following the keypad cluster rebuild on this Beogram 4000 turntable, the next step was to address the mechanical switches that control its operation. These switches are grouped into two clusters: one set located under the carriage that dictates tonearm positioning, and another positioned near the solenoid. The solenoid-activated switches are critical for engaging the tracking mechanism, initiating output when the stylus is in the groove, and regulating the solenoid power upon the arm’s descent.

item.title: Beogram 4000 AC Platter Motor Restoration
item.description: I recently obtained a Beogram 4000 AC platter motor from Massachusetts that had a knocking sound. Adjusting the voltage and tilt did not fix the problem. To address this, I typically disassemble the motor and submerge the housing parts in motor oil. Using a vacuum, I ensure the oil fills the material pores. Below is a picture of the motor upon arrival: I drilled out the rivets and disassembled the motor:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival From West Virginia
item.description: A Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable from West Virginia recently arrived for a complete restoration. The turntable was in good condition and shipped in a Beolover container. Initial inspection revealed no significant damage to the dust cover or hinges. The aluminum surfaces are in good condition, but the keypad has some wear. This will be addressed by installing a Beolover Commander remote control module, which allows for keypad-free operation. The plinth is well-preserved, with minimal damage to the front corners, which are prone to wear.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Adjusting the Sub-Chassis and the Platter, and RPM Calibration
item.description: Today was dedicated to adjusting the platter and sub-chassis on a Beogram 4002 (5513) that I’m working on. I aimed to align the platter’s aluminum surface with the surrounding panels, center the sub-chassis within the transport locks’ limits, and ensure the arms were parallel to the aluminum surfaces. It’s intricate work involving aligning numerous components. After gaining experience with this process, I achieved a satisfactory result, aligning the Beogram to specifications.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): DC Motor Restoration and Yet Another Exciting Aspect of Achieving RPM Stability
item.description: To restore the platter drive system of a Beogram 4002 (5513) DC motor, several upgrades are necessary. These include installing modern multi-turn RPM trimmers, a new RPM relay, replacing the RPM trimmer backlights with LEDs, and refreshing the motor bearings with oil. Testing the RPM stability after each step reveals their individual impact on performance. This particular Beogram 4002 had already undergone most of these improvements, with the exception of the motor restoration.

item.title: Beogram 8000 Type 5613: Wisconsin project is ready for record play
item.description: The Beogram 8000 turntable has undergone service manual checks and adjustments. The power supply voltages are within acceptable ranges, and the forward/reverse scanning LDR adjustments and tracking force are calibrated. A test play confirms the Beogram’s readiness for listening tests after component reinstallation. The supply voltage readings at the filter capacitors and regulator outputs are as follows: +15 VDC, -15 VDC, and +5 VDC. The forward and reverse scanning sensors (LDR devices) have been adjusted to an idle voltage of around 650 mVdc using a three-pin test connector.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Final Adjustments and Test Drive with Freddy Hubbard's 1975 Album "Polar AC"
item.description: Restoring a Beogram 4002 turntable to its former glory is always fulfilling. This particular restoration involved several meticulous adjustments before I could relish Freddie Hubbard’s music. The first crucial step was aligning the platter and arms flawlessly. Next, I had to align the platter with its surrounding aluminum panels while ensuring the chassis remained suspended, delicately balanced on its spring-loaded arms. This procedure requires precision as the tolerances for these adjustments are minimal.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration: A New Tool on the Bench and the Importance of the Orientation of the Top Bearing
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC platter motor was acquired for restoration. Evidence suggested prior repair attempts on the motor, including scratches on the bearing assembly and damaged brushes. Upon disassembly, it was clear the bearings hadn’t been properly oiled. A vacuum oil infusion process was conducted on both the top and bottom bearings. After cleaning and reassembly, a short circuit was detected, pointing to faulty spark snubbers. The old spark snubbers were replaced with modern TVS devices.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (I)
item.description: While I’m waiting for a part for a Beocord 9000 cassette deck, I’ve started restoring another one with faulty displays. It seems cassettes are making a comeback! I’m even hoping for new tapes and maybe even a revival of the Sony Walkman II. This particular Beocord 9000 has a very dim display: [Image of dim display] The “Time Cal” bulb is also weak, a common issue. I began with the VU meter (or Peak Program Meter), as I haven’t refurbished this type before.

item.title: Beogram 4000: Restoring the Hood
item.description: I finally decided to refurbish the dust cover of the Beogram 4000 turntable from Norway, a task that takes me around 3 hours. I had been putting it off because I was enjoying working on a custom transformer for a Beomaster 4000 receiver. As is common with vintage turntables, the dust cover on this Beogram 4000 was showing its age. It had numerous scratches and blemishes, as you can see here:

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Main Board Rework and Start of Speed Test #3
item.description: I visited Mouser to acquire some components for my Beogram project. However, upon commencing work on the main board, I realized I lacked a couple of 5KΩ multi-turn trimmers, essential for the 45 RPM and 33 1/3 RPM speed control (labeled 1R14 and 1R15). While I could order the parts, delivery wouldn’t be possible until Monday, and I was eager to keep the project moving. Here’s a photo of the Beogram’s main board before removal:

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Power Supply and Replacing the Reservoir Capacitors with a 3D Printed Fixture
item.description: It seems Bang & Olufsen made two versions of the Beogram 4002 (5513) with different power supply setups, both designed with a possible CD4 upgrade in mind. The output board could be swapped for one with a pre-amplifier and CD4 decoder. One version powers the CD4 board directly from the main PCB’s 30V rail and uses a single 4000uF capacitor. My Beogram 4002 uses a separate power supply for the CD4 board, with its own transformer winding, bridge rectifier, and 1000uF capacitor.

item.title: Beogram 4002 Type 5513: Adjusting/Calibrating the Detector Arm Circuit
item.description: The Beogram 4002 turntable is nearly ready for use, with most of the necessary adjustments and calibrations finalized. As planned, the record detection circuit needed adjustment due to a low measurement. Utilizing insights from Beolover’s blog post on the Beogram 4002 record detection circuit, the circuit was calibrated to align with the service manual’s specifications. Two components on the main board, 1R26 (a 1MΩ resistor) and 1TR3 (an NPN BC548C transistor), are key in fine-tuning the signal from the record detection circuit.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Final Adjustments and Test Drive with Freddie Hubbard's Liquid Love
item.description: Following the installation of the Beolover 4002 Commander remote control and internal RIAA pre-amplifier, it was time for final adjustments before testing the turntable. The first step was tracking feedback adjustment. A blue trimmer on the tracking sensor LED light source simplified the fine-tuning of the feedback after the coarse mechanical adjustment of the sensor housing. Next, the subclasses and platter height were adjusted, followed by the arm lowering limit. The lowering limit ensures the needle can descend below the record surface without hitting the platter ribs if the record detection fails.

item.title: Beocord 5000 (4715/4716): Extraction of Drive Mechanism
item.description: Having restored a Beocord 5000 before, I’ve refined the process of removing the tape mechanism, simplifying the steps from my previous post and video. I began by removing the plexiglass cover for polishing, which provided better access to the tape mechanism. To prepare for a full recap, I also lifted the preamplifier and radio amplifier boards. The photo shows the unit opened up: ‘Chartz’ from Beoworld.org suggested leaving the solenoid in place during removal, which led me to realize that even loosening the solenoid fixture is unnecessary.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacement of Sensor Arm Bulb with an LED Assembly
item.description: During the restoration of a Beogram 4002 turntable, the light bulb in the sensor arm, crucial for record detection, was replaced with a longer-lasting LED. To ensure compatibility with the turntable’s bulb detection circuit, which disables record detection if a bulb failure is detected, the LED assembly was designed to mimic the current draw of the original bulb. LEDs inherently use less current, so a parallel current path was added to the LED board to compensate.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5503): A First Look
item.description: I recently began restoring a Beogram 4002 (5503) AC-motor turntable purchased from eBay. I had sent the seller specific packaging instructions and a sturdy double-boxed container, which they thankfully followed, resulting in the unit arriving undamaged. Initial observations are as follows: The aluminum surfaces are generally in good shape, just needing a cleaning. The platter, in particular, has remarkably few imperfections. The keypad shows typical signs of use, with fingerprints visible on the most frequently pressed keys.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5501): Replacement of End Groove Detection Light Bulb with an LED
item.description: Following the restoration of the Beogram 4002 (5501) RPM trimmer panel, the focus shifted to the malfunctioning end groove detection mechanism. This ingenious mechanism utilizes a light bulb, a photoresistor, and an encoder wheel acting as a pulley to detect when the carriage accelerates after the record’s final track. By identifying this movement, the mechanism reduces the return time to the home position for records with extended end grooves, such as 12" singles or certain LPs with shorter playtimes.

item.title: Beogram 4000: A New Arrival from Massachusetts
item.description: It’s always wonderful to see a returning customer! Earlier this year, I restored a Beogram 4000 for a client in Massachusetts. Now, I’m excited to work on another Beogram 4000 he’s sent my way. It seems one can never have too many Beograms! The Beogram 4000 arrived safely, shipped securely in a Beolover box. It was accompanied by a thoughtful gift for Beolover, for which I am incredibly grateful. This beautiful reissue of “Waltz for Debby” by the Bill Evans Trio, a legendary jazz record, is a 180g pressing.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Replacing the Speed Indictor Light Bulbs with RGB LEDs
item.description: During the wait for a 3D-printed part for a Beogram 4002 turntable restoration, the author decided to upgrade its speed indicator lights. Using a method from a previous video, they replaced the incandescent bulbs with RGB LEDs for a more authentic look. The original setup with incandescent bulbs was documented before the upgrade. The new setup utilizes both the red and green diodes of an RGB LED for a natural appearance, addressing the issue of amber LEDs failing to illuminate red scale markers properly.

item.title: Beogram 4002 DC Motor Restoration - Oil Infusion, New Spark Snubbers and an Ultrasonic Cleaning
item.description: A Beogram 4002 DC platter motor was recently sent in for repair. Initial testing showed the motor was barely functional. To address this, the motor was disassembled, and the bearings were removed for lubrication. The bearings, designed to be porous and oil-filled, were treated with a vacuum oil infusion process. This process, evidenced by vigorous bubbling, helps to replenish the oil within the bearings over time. After a few days, the bubbling subsided, indicating the bearings were adequately filled with oil, and they were removed from the oil bath.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A First Look (What a Packaging Mess!)
item.description: I recently purchased a Beogram 4002 (5513) on eBay for a customer. Although the seller described it as being in very good cosmetic condition and included a new Soundsmith SMMC20 EN cartridge, the turntable arrived poorly packaged in a damaged box. Thankfully, the turntable itself was inside a second box with better protective materials. Upon opening the inner box, I was relieved to find the Beogram 4002 in pristine condition, as advertised.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A First Impression
item.description: I recently began working on a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, which was exciting to receive in its original box and packaging. Upon opening it, I was greeted by a pleasant surprise—a pristine MMC20CL cartridge was mounted on the tonearm. Thankfully, it was protected by a cover and had been gently pressed against the styrofoam, keeping it safe during shipping. Carefully, I removed the styrofoam and cartridge, relieved to find the cantilever was still centered and undamaged.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Restoration of the Peak Program Meter with SMD LEDs (III)
item.description: This article, the third in a series about restoring a Beocord 9000’s peak program meters (PPM), focuses on installing and calibrating the rebuilt PPM. The initial step involved switching the original current limiting resistors with values suitable for modern SMD LEDs. These LEDs are more efficient and brighter, requiring significantly larger resistors to match the original brightness. Testing showed that 470 Ohm and 330 Ohm resistors for red and green LEDs, respectively, produced slightly brighter output compared to the original 180 Ohm and 120 Ohm resistors.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Repair of a Broken Out Leaf Spring in the Tape Mechanism
item.description: During the restoration of a Beocord 9000, a loose part was discovered within the device’s casing. This component turned out to be the left leaf spring responsible for securing the head carrier. A comparison with the corresponding right spring revealed that a small ball bearing, crucial for smooth head movement, was missing. Further investigation determined the ball bearing’s diameter to be 2.5 mm, and a readily available supply was procured. The broken plastic piece attached to the loose spring indicated that the original assembly, constantly under tension, had given way.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Restoration of the Hood
item.description: The final stage of my recent Beogram 4002 (5513) restoration project involved reviving the dust cover. Like many Beograms of its era, the cover required attention, particularly the rubber bumpers which needed replacing. The extent of the damage is evident in this photo: Fortunately, the scratches weren’t severe. A 320-grit sanding step effectively leveled the plexiglass, preparing it for polishing to regain its transparency: After approximately ten stages of polishing, using progressively finer sandpaper and polishing cloths, the cover regained its shine:

item.title: Bay Area Beogram 8002: Some cabinet work
item.description: The Beogram 8002’s internal components are ready to be placed back into the cabinet, but the cabinet needs some attention first. While this Beogram’s cabinet is in good condition overall, there are a few things that need to be fixed, as mentioned in the initial assessment (linked in the original text). The first step was to remove the aluminum deck lid. The previous re-attachment used overly thick double-sided tape that created too much space.

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): Replacement of a Wobbly Carriage Pulley with a New Aluminum Unit
item.description: As I was finishing the restoration of my Beogram 4002 (5523), I noticed a concerning noise coming from the carriage when it moved quickly, especially when returning to its starting position. This led me to believe there was an issue with the carriage pulley. Upon inspection, I discovered that the pulley was cracked, which is a common problem with this model. It seems the original plastic can’t handle the stress from the setscrew over time and eventually cracks.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Replacing the Incandescent Indicator Light Bulbs with SMD LEDs
item.description: During the restoration of a Beocord 9000, two indicator lights presented problems. One had a typical issue with a broken lead, while the other had become dim due to a deteriorating filament. To address this, I opted to use SMD LEDs as replacements, similar to a method I’ve used for Beomaster 8000 units, documented on my blog. This provides lasting stability and safeguards against potential shipping damage. However, the Beocord 9000 has more compact reflector housings compared to the Beomaster 8000, necessitating a redesign of the PCBs for the LEDs.

item.title: Beocord 9000: Total Recap - Replacement of all Electrolytic Capacitors
